snippet: The proposal had been seen as a move by Prime Minister Viktor Orban to choke off one of the last sources of information not controlled by him and his allies.
abstract: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary says that his government will abandon, at least for now, a proposed tax on Internet usage that drew tens of thousands of demonstrators to the streets; protest organizers, who had charged that proposed tax was attempt by Orban’s right-wing government to choke off one of the last sources of information not controlled by him and his allies, call for victory celebrations across country.

byline.contributor: Palko Karasz contributed reporting from London.

lead_paragraph: The proposal had been seen as a move by Prime Minister Viktor Orban to choke off one of the last sources of information not controlled by him and his allies.

headline.main: Hungary Drops Internet Tax Plan After Public Outcry
headline.print_headline: Hungary Drops Internet Tax Plan After Public Outcry
